bibl.title: Letter from H. Carter Redd to Philip Showalter Hench, January 23, 1948

div1.p: Redd discusses Carter's extant correspondence, noting that much of it consists of social matters regarding Carter's daughter, Laura. Redd discusses Laura's important role in her father's work.

div1.head: Letter from H. Carter Redd to Philip Showalter Hench, January 23, 1948
div1.opener:
Commissioner of Accounts and Commissioner in
Chancery of Circuit Court of Hanover County
H. CARTER REDD
ATTORNEY-AT-LAW
1104 TRAVELERS BUILDING
RICHMOND, VA.
Jan. 23rd. 1948
Dr. Phillip S. Hench,
Mayo Clinic,
Rochester, Minn.
My dear Doctor:-
div1.p:
I am sending the copy of your letter of the 20th to me to Dr. H. R.
Carter, Jr. in Birmingham, Ala. asking his permission to send the
trukns on to you.

There are three large trunks. You will have quite a task
before you, and I know that there is a lot of “stuff” which can be
thrown away.

The “stuff” in the chest which I discarded, was mostly
social matters in regard to (then) Miss Laura Carter.

She was a brilliant woman, and was her father's constant
attendant when he was confined to his bed, and for eighteen months
writing the history of Yellow Fever for the Rockfellows, which
she completed with the help of Dr. Frost as editor after her
father's death. She presented her father with a certificate
of graduation from a business school in ahort hand and typeing on
his return home from an absence of three month in field work, and
thus not only took his dictation, but secured the reference books
from the Library in Washington and reviewed them for her father.

She was called on to make talks in regard to the work,
and was very fond of society, and the “stuff” I discarded or rather
weeded out was mostly that and social letters, in which I should
think you would not care to bother with.

There is such a mass of letters &c. in the trunks that I
would take too long to go through, and hope that Dr. Carter will
allow me to send it on as is. ( Lazy, Am I not?)

I will send you copy of the other letter I found from
Reed.

I might say right here, that Dr. Carter said that Reed
had always been perfectly fair and had always given him full
credit for his part in the yellow fever work.

closer.seg:
P. S.
My stenographer is out, which accounts for the bad typing I
have done above.
